Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Leukocyte adhesion and mechanical arrest in a model capillary

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tees
0547165

During inflammation and sepsis, white blood cells can get trapped in capillaries, especially in the lung. Based on the physics of the capillary environment, it is hypothesized that cell arrest in capillaries can involve both mechanical and biochemical adhesive forces. To test this hypothesis, an adhesion assay has been devised in which cells are aspirated into capillary-sized micropipettes coated with endothelial cell adhesion molecules (ECAMs). The project will: 1) verify by both experiment and simulation that much lower surface densities of ECAMs are needed to mediate firm adhesion in capillaries than are required in larger vessels; 2) test the hypothesis that changes in contact area and mechanical properties for cells aspirated into micropipettes can enhance adhesion in the capillary environment; 3) validate theoretical predictions for the mechanical arrest position of cells in tapering vessels. The work has implications for treatment of sepsis and also for prevention of cancer metastasis, since many cancer cell types also get trapped in the lung. Techniques and concepts at the interface between the physical and biological sciences are increasingly required for research in industry and academia. A laboratory course in biophysics will be developed to fill this need and to create an online database of educational resources. Both the research and educational work will involve the training of physics and engineering students in techniques and concepts at the interface between the physical and biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Capillaries, the smallest type of blood vessel, are significantly smaller than most of the blood cells that have to move through them. Red blood cells pass through capillaries easily, but larger and more rigid white blood cells (which fight infection) need to deform to pass through. During inflammation and sepsis, white blood cells can get trapped in the small, tortuous capillary networks of the lung. We hypothesized that cell trapping in capillaries could involve both mechanical and biochemical adhesive forces. To test this hypothesis, we developed a testbed system in which cells were sucked into capillary-sized glass tubes (micropipettes) that were coated with two of the adhesion molecules that are normally found on the cells lining blood vessels (P-selectin and ICAM-1).

We used the micropipette testbed system to show that the large contact area with the vessel wall that cells develop when they are forced into capillaries leads to unusually durable adhesion. We also found that neutrophils (the most common type of white blood cell) moved slowly along the micropipettes with a speed that decreased as the P-selectin concentration increased. We showed that the gap width between the cell surface and the micropipette wall decreased as the concentration of adhesion molecules coating the micropipette increased. This gives us the input data we need to constrain future computer simulations of the creeping motion for neutrophils in micropipettes that will clarify which of several potential mechanisms might explain the creeping motion.

The diameter of lung capillaries often tapers. We examined neutrophil motion in tapering micropipettes and showed that it is unstable, with large velocity fluctuations. No trapping of neutrophils was observed, but there was a point where cells slowed down drastically, most likely due to compression of the less deformable cell nucleus.

As an extension of this testbed system to a different cell type, the motion of breast cancer cells in micropipettes was also examined. Much like with neutrophils adhesion in lung microcirculation, the mechanism for how cancer cells are spread to distant organs through blood circulation is not completely determined. Cancer cells might be trapped by adhesion molecule-mediated binding between cancer cells and target vessel wall cells or by an inability to enter into the smallest blood vessels because the cells are too large or stiff. Two breast cancer cell lines were assessed, and we found that P-selectins could mediate the creeping adhesion of both cancer cell lines.

In parallel work, we tracked the Brownian motion of granules inside white blood cells to measure the local mechanical properties of neutrophils. These experiments showed that the central region of neutrophils that have been aspirated into micropipettes is stiffer than the leading end cap. When cells are brought into micropipettes that have been coated with ICAM-1, these regional differences are preserved, but all regions become stiffer. This is consistent with the hypothesis that there are changes in cell mechanical properties that facilitate arrest in tapering vessels when the vessels express adhesion molecules.

Experiments for a new laboratory course in biophysics have been developed based around an Optical Tweezers system. Students were able to perform experiments on Brownian motion and optical trapping of microparticles. An undergraduate student developed protocols for a new lab that used the optical tweezers to stall beads coated with the molecular motor kinesin moving on microtubules. An additional lab module in microfluidics was added later. The optical tweezer system has been showcased in demonstrations to the general public at the Physics & Astronomy Department Open Houses in 2007, 2009, 2011, 2013 and 2015 and for the Young Scholars Ohio program for middle and high school students in 2011, 2013 and 2015.

 

Broader impact:

The testbed system for the capillary environment should lead to insights about cell motion in the capillary regime. The work on developing experiments and demonstrations of Brownian motion, optical tweezers, and microfluidics has improved resources for interdisciplinary training of students and for exposing the general public to the physics of the biological microworld.


Last Modified: 12/29/2016
Modified by: David Tees
